Congressman, this level of coordination between the Democrats and teachers unions who have them in their back pocket. This is not science, this is politics.

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE (R-LA)
utterances.utterance: Yes, Laura. And what we exposed through this is that it was political science, not medical science that CDC used to put their guidance out on school reopenings. And in fact, CDC was getting ready to come out with guidance that would have been more favorable towards opening schools. And then the teachers unions were given weeks - over a week before it came out. We're given a sneak copy of it that no one else got that we've been able to find. And said, "OK, what do you think about this?" And we had uncovered emails between the CDC Director and the union president saying, "Wait a minute, we don't like this. We want new language that makes it easier to close schools." And they actually, the unions, gave different language to the CDC. And then CDC's final language was almost word-for-word verbatim from what the teachers union said. I don't know of any other group, surely no parents groups that got this kind of VIP access. And in fact, I asked the CDC Director today in the hearing, to give me a list of anybody else that they gave this kind of access to change the documents.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: We have one of your exchanges. This is when you asked Walensky about the CDC's just plain involvement with the unions. Watch.

utterances.speaker: ROCHELLE WALENSKY, CDC DIRECTOR
utterances.utterance: These work discussions had happened in the beginning of February of 2021, days after I entered into this position. We needed to get our schools open. We, in that context, engaged as we often do with organizations and groups that are impacted by our guidance and our recommendations at the agency.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: First of all, she's reading her response. She knows she's in hot water. So she's - you can see her reading it. And second of all, I mean, the teachers unions, we know from the Chicago experience, Congressman, they never want to go back. They - if they could stay remote forever, the unions would be happy to stay. Just like your colleagues never want to come back to do actual voting in-person. So why would we ever ask for their guidance since they don't want to come back to work?

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.utterance: Right. And ultimately, what they said was, we want stronger guidance to keep schools closed, to keep millions of children out of schools. And keep in mind too, Laura, this is all going on under the backdrop when the Justice Department is calling parents, domestic terrorists, for showing up at school board meetings. So I asked the CDC Director, give me names of parent groups that you consulted and gave the same kind of VP act - VIP access. They couldn't give me a name. And I said, I want to know, were parents allowed to have the same kind of ability to change the science, like the unions were able to give to keep schools closed. And she couldn't give me a single name, because it was the union bosses who said, "Look, don't come up with this until you give us new ability to shut down schools". And they paid off their friends and gave them the language.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Oh, and I will say in closing that Maggie Hassan in New Hampshire; Mark Kelly in Arizona; Cortes Masto in Nevada, you are partly responsible for this. You get the donations from the teachers unions. Warnock as well. Voters have to take note of this. Your kids were locked out of these schools for no reason. Congressman, thank you.

utterances.speaker: SCALISE
utterances.utterance: And it was about keeping kids out of schools, Laura. So we're going to keep having this.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes. Thank you for doing that. All right. And educational entities weren't just keeping kids out of schools, they were discovering new ways to pollute their minds. Breitbart reporting, that "Through teacher training lectures, like cultivating anti- racist and activists in kindergarten and decolonizing the minds of second graders." The nation's leading accreditation association for private schools, it's called the National Association of Independent Schools, is instructing educators to adopt what's called a race-essentialist curriculum for children. One of their chief instructors is a former Black Panther.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: That notion of diversity that we really reached out to include, for instance, the dominant culture of white students and teachers in this work. I think it's important to have representation in what our students are studying all the way down to pre-K. And talking about things like race, like gender, like social class for our youngest learners. I think the whole notion of assessing with an equity lens is so critical. It's there that we begin to see the bias surface.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Joining me now Bob Woodson, founder and CEO of the Woodson Center. Bob, we keep thinking it can't get worse. But now they're all exposing themselves. Your take on this. BOB WOODSON, THE WOODSON CENTER FOUNDER & CEO: Well, first of all. Thanks for having me on, Laura. This whole emphasis on race, it really is a flip side is, I think, white progressive narcissism, that somehow that the destiny and future of black America depends upon what white people do or do not do. Dr. King really warned against that in her letter from a Birmingham jail when he said the greatest stumbling block to black progress is not the white citizen's council or the KKK. It is the white moderate, that lukewarm acceptance from people of good will is more difficult to tolerate than outright rejection of people of ill-will. And some of these progressives that are teaching this poison to our children, in one sense, are worse than bigots. They're worse than hardline bigots, because they are really preaching self-annihilation. Every five minutes, Laura, a child is shot in America. I know of a black woman who lost all four of her children, her four sons, to homicide before the age of 30. There is a crisis in America, and the answer to those kinds of challenges is not going to come from teaching white people to be less racist. It is narcissistic to believe that, but also harmful to the nation. It's poisonous.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bob.

utterances.speaker: WOODSON
utterances.utterance: And I don't want to hear another white person say to me I cannot confront this truth, Bob Woodson, I'm white, I can't say that, only you can. That's crap. White America has to summon the courage to stand up against these progressive bigots and pursue truth

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, Bob, we were talking about this in relation -- sorry to interrupt, but we were talking about this if relation to Disney, and that's more the sexual propagandizing. But it's this corporate environment that they're hoisting on employees where it's the equity, diversity, equity, inclusion agenda, which on its face, that sounds fine. But when you dig into it, it's a not about tolerance. This is about you must believe, you must think. And it just creates an intolerable environment for free thought and free expression, period, and learning.

utterances.speaker: WOODSON
utterances.utterance: It's not only intolerance but it's insulting. But they're using the black issue about justice as the reason for the need for it. And I'm saying that that is just no shared by majority of black Americans. You talked about Governor DeSantis. He won because 100,000 low-income black people voted for him. He only won by 32,000 votes because of his position vouchers on education.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bingo.

utterances.speaker: WOODSON
utterances.utterance: Even though Obama and Oprah Winfrey came in to campaign for Gillam. So black Americans, low-income black Americans do not share this passion for racial diversity that is being thrust on them by black and white elites.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, white guilt. That always comes back. Bob we've get to.

utterances.speaker: WOODSON
utterances.utterance: White guilt is poisonous.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Bob, your perspective is so needed tonight. Thank you very much And the academy just released some news on the Will Smith smackdown, and Chris Rock just offered his first response moments ago. Raymond Arroyo has it all. "Seen and Unseen" is next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's time for our "Seen and Unseen" segment where we explore the stories behind the headlines. And for that we turn to FOX News contributor Raymond Arroyo. Ray, Biden was on stage asking Congress for more money today.

utterances.speaker: RAYMOND ARROYO, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Yes, for COVID no less, on that little White House stage, Laura. As the pandemic wanes and cases plummet, Biden says he needs hundreds of millions of dollars for the next vaccine, and he's launching what every American yearns for at the end of the pandemic, a commemorative website.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: Today I'm announcing the launch of COVID.gov, COVID.gov, a one-stop shop. We've already stood up 2,000 test and treat sites across the country. I've worked so hard to get our lives, we've worked so hard, we, all of us have worked so hard to get our lives back. So now I'm going to get my second booster shot. I'm not sure why I'm doing it on stage.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: "I'm not sure why I'm doing it on stage." Neither are we. He's still pushing boosters Laura, he even as that Pfizer document dump showed that the shot suppresses your immunity for seven days after injection. And you should see this website. It looks for the child built it. Are there really Americans searching for masks, wondering how do I find masks at this point? Good lord.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Just go to the airport, United, they have a whole bunch of masks there. It's simple, no problem.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: They have got piles of them nobody's using anymore. Laura, this is a FOX News alert, the Academy in a new statement says Will Smith violated their code of conduct when he hit comedian Chris Rock during the Oscars. The Academy revealing "Mr. Smith was asked to leave the ceremony and refused. We also recognize," they go on, "we could have handled this situation differently." You don't say, Academy? The Academy says it will take weeks for them to decide whether to expel --

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Weeks?

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: -- or suspend Smith from membership or levy some other sanction. Laura, I told you on Monday what I thought they should do. He should be out of the Academy all together. What do you think should happen here?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Yes, the guy got up off his seat and smacked another guy as millions of people were watching around the world. People say he's a really nice guy, maybe he's really nice. Chris Rock is, I guess, a really nice guy. I don't care if you're a nice guy. You can't do that. You can't do it.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: And Chris Rock tonight for the first time spoke out. He's at a Boston comedy club, and he said he's still processing what happened, but he said I will respond and it will be serious and funny. There were hoots and hollers of "F- Will Smith" throughout the comedy club tonight. So shows you where the people are. And today, Oscar cohost Wanda Sykes reacted this way on "The Ellen Show."

utterances.speaker: WANDA SYKES, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: It was sickening. It was absolutely -- I physically felt ill. And I'm still a little traumatized by it.

utterances.speaker: ELLEN DEGENERES, TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: Me, too. You don't let someone do something like that and get away with it and be rewarded.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Precisely. Ellen has more common sense and understanding and gravity of this moment than even the White House where the comms director today refused to condemn Smith's violence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I don't have any official comment from the White House on the altercation. I know the president was not able to watch the Oscars, didn't see it. So I don't have anything, I don't have any official comments from him or from the White House on this.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: He gets to sleep at 7:00.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: Maybe it's because Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith gave $5,600 to Biden and hosted a fundraiser for his predecessor, Barack Obama. But you know Laura, the problem with all of this is, some people say move on, he apologized, move on. No, no. It's a cultural inflection point, and it glamourizes and normalizes these ad hoc beatings and smackdowns you see all across America. You don't need a leading actor like this, particularly one that families identify with, enacting this violence, and it shouldn't be celebrated or condoned. And when O.J. Simpson comes out to support you, Laura, as he did Will Smith, you're probably not the innocent party. Maybe Smith can play "The Juice" next. And there are those peculiar Instagram posts. Did you see these, Laura? Will, he posted this before the Oscars. Before the ceremony he wrote "Me and Jada Pinkett got all dressed up to choose chaos." Then there was this bizarre video. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Good morning, everyone. God has let me live every day and I am about to make it everyone's problem.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Aren't we a little old for that.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: That is weird.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: It's all the infantilization of adulthood in Hollywood, too. When you're doing a voiceover for a cartoon or an animated series, that's one thing. But you're a grown man with children and a lot of people look up to you, and it's just, it's lame. I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: ARROYO
utterances.utterance: I found that creepy and a little psychologically disturbing, frankly, as a kind of a preview of what was to come. Very odd.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Ellen was right, OK, Ellen was right. Raymond, great report. Thank you so much And so what happens if Joe Biden doesn't run for a second term? Well, as Barack Obama's former pollster told "Vanity Fair," Plan B is complete f-ing chaos. Ari Fleischer and Victor Davis Hanson are here on that next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: But the better question is, how low can Joe go in the polls? And how long will vulnerable Democrats in choppy waters tie themselves to this sinking anvil?

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Well, that question I posed last night seems a little bit prescient. A new Quinnipiac poll released a few hours ago shows that Joe Biden's approval is now at 36 percent. With almost three years still left in his first term, many are already looking for the exits for the 2024 contingency plans, but those aren't going well either. Obama pollster Cornell Belcher telling "Vanity Fair" "Plan B is complete f-ing chaos." Democrats are already feeling out their options, so Pete Buttigieg, Kamala Harris, the Rock. Joining me now, Ari Fleischer, former White House press secretary, FOX News contributor, and Victor Davis Hanson, Hoover Institution senior fellow. Ari, first the media confirms the Hunter news that we all knew last year, and now they're already talking 2024 replacement. A part of me wonders if the media is now beginning to turn on Joe.

utterances.speaker: ARI FLEISCHER, FORMER WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: Laura, look, none of us should pretend that Joe Biden is going to run for reelection. He'll be an 82-year-old president to begin his second term if he were to win. And after the blowout the Democrats are going to go through in November, they are going to just call on Biden to step aside so a new generation can run. And you sent me back down memory lane -- 27 Democrats ran for president when the last open seat was there in 2019-2020. We remember Biden, we remember Harris, we remember Buttigieg. But Beto O'Rourke ran, Jay Inslee ran, Marianne Williamson ran. Do you remember all these names -- 27. It's going to be the same situation in the next open seat. Everybody in the Democrat Party is going to run. It's going to be wide open chaos.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Victor, the Democrats are a little pollyannish about the midterms.

utterances.speaker: REP. STENY HOYER, (D-MD) MAJORITY LEADER
utterances.utterance: I'm hopeful and I believe, I believe that we're gold to hold our majority in the House and expand our majority in the Senate.

utterances.speaker: NANCY PELOSI, (D-CA) HOUSE SPEAKER
utterances.utterance: We have every intention of winning. It is absolutely essential for our democracy that we win.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: Now we look at 2022. I want to tell my Republican friends, get ready, pal. You're going to be in for a problem.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Victor, that's what he told all our adversaries when he was coming in, America's back. Are these people blind, pretending, or are they just delusional at this point?

utterances.speaker: VICTOR DAVIS HANSON, HOOVER INSTITUTE SENIOR FELLOW
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think we've never been in this territory before because the real crisis is whether he'll be able to make it through his first term. And the vice-presidential solution to the presidential problem is worse. The solution's worse than the problem. So I guess you go back, as Ari said, to the 2020 candidate field. But the problem there, Laura, is that all of their agendas have been actualized. They got what they wanted and they're a disaster. When you look at the individual people, Beto's going to lose the Texas race, Buttigieg has been a disaster as transportation secretary, booker had a t-bone gush the other day. There's no there there. And in the past when the Democratic Party was hijacked in 72 by McGovern and 88 by Dukakis, there was a solution. They got a southern governor like Jimmy Carter or Bill Clinton. Not that they were moderate, but they posed as moderate. I don't see anybody there. Gavin Newsom, maybe Jared Polis in Colorado, or maybe they can bring back Andrew Cuomo. But there's not the traditional solution of going hard left and destroying the party as they had in the past.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Part of that is they kicked all the conservatives out of the Democrat Party. There is no one left. Joe Manchin, that's not going to fly. Ari, they are so desperate they were talking about the Rock, and also, they mentioned Michelle Obama. And they keep going back to that. Ted Cruz mentioned her last night that really, that's maybe their only hope. But if we have soaring chaos oversees and inflation at home, I'm not sure a celebrity is going to change much.

utterances.speaker: FLEISCHER
utterances.utterance: Look, Laura, the biggest story in politics in the last 25 years is the shift leftward inside the Democratic Party. You have six Democratic Socialists now serving in the House of Representatives. And the Democrat Party, which used to be somewhat of a moderate party, is now an overwhelmingly liberal socialist party, and it's the kiss of death. It's one of the reasons Hispanics are increasingly becoming Republican. They're kicking everybody off except the far let progressives who will never be happy, and their agenda can never be achieved. So the Democrats are going to be a shell of a party, and it's going to happen because Biden is not going to be able to run for reelection. And this is going to start the day after Election Day. In seven months, that's when you're going to hear the Democrats go to Biden and say, you need to announce you're not running. We need time to organize our campaigns. We need to know that the field is clear. This is going to be a disaster for the Democrats. 2024 is a long way away. We'll see electorally what happens. But getting there, a wide open field of chaos.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: And Victor, really quickly, AOC said the party needs to go farther left. That's the reason it's floundering.

utterances.speaker: HANSON
utterances.utterance: You and I talked about that, Laura, after the Virginia election, and also in the school board in San Francisco and we said that they're never going to be moderate. They went harder left after they were humiliated in Virginia and the school board in San Francisco. So for them the solution to socialism and extremism is worse than the problem, so they're not going to change.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: From socialism to Marxism, full blown communism. Ari, Victor, great to see you both And up next, Kamala was at it today. The Last Bite, well, I guess we'll just call it another word salad, next.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: Now, try to follow what Kamala told the Jamaican delegation today.

utterances.speaker: KAMALA HARRIS, (D) VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: For Jamaica, one of the issues that has been presented as an issue that is economic in way of its impact has been the pandemic. So to that end we are announcing today also that we will assist Jamaica in COVID recovery by assisting in terms of the recovery efforts in Jamaica that have been essential.

utterances.speaker: INGRAHAM
utterances.utterance: What? All right, get your Freedom Matters gear, all American made, and LauraIngraham.com, new hoodie, camo for charity. "GUTFELD!" next.
